questions.question_text:
A developer accidentally launched a VM (virtual machine) outside of the Terraform workflow and ended up with two servers with the same name. They don’t know which VM Terraform manages but do have a list of all active VM IDs.

Which of the following methods could you use to discover which instance Terraform manages?

discussion.content:

B will also work.

Selected Answer: C
I vote C

Selected Answer: C
https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/cli/commands/state/list

https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/cli/commands/state/show

choices.C: Run terraform state list to find the names of all VMs, then run terraform state show for each of them to find which VM ID Terraform manages
choices.D: Use terraform refresh/code to find out which IDs are already part of state
choices.A: Run terraform taint/code on all the VMs to recreate them
choices.B: Update the code to include outputs for the ID of all VMs, then run terraform plan to view the outputs

choices.A: Edit the state file directly just before running terraform apply
choices.C: Write the value to a file and specify the file with the -var-file flag
choices.B: Set the variable value on the command line with the -var flag

If a particular provider already has a selection recorded in the lock file, Terraform will always re-select that version for installation, even if a newer version has become available. You can override that behavior by adding the -upgrade option when you run terraform init, in which case Terraform will disregard the existing selections and once again select the newest available version matching the version constraint.
